introduction.p: Evaluate each of the following indefinite integrals.

solution.p:
First, using u = x^2 and dv = \sin(x) dx, we get du = 2x dx and v = -\cos(x). So
\int x^2 \sin(x) dx = -x^2 \cos(x) + 2 \int x \cos(x) dx . Now, for \int x \cos(x) dx, we use u = x and dv = \cos(x) and get du = dx and v =\sin(x). So \int x^2 \sin(x) dx \amp = -x^2 \cos(x) + 2 \left( x \sin(x) - \int \sin(x) dx \right)\amp = -x^2 \cos(x) + 2x \sin(x) + 2 \cos(x) + c

Using u = \ln(t) and dv = t^3 dt, we get du = \dfrac{1}{t} dt and v = \dfrac{1}{4} t^4. So \int t^3 \ln(t) dt \amp = \frac{1}{4} t^4 \ln(t) - \frac{1}{4} \int t^3 dt\amp = \frac{1}{4} t^4 \ln(t) - \frac{1}{4} \cdot \frac{1}{4} t^4 + c\amp = \frac{1}{4} t^4 \ln(t) - \frac{1}{16} t^4 + c

hint.p: You'll have to integrate by parts twice.

solution.p:
We use u = e^z and dv = \sin(z) dz. This gives du = e^z dz and v = -\cos(z), and
\int e^z \sin(z) dz = -e^z \cos(z) + \int e^z \cos(z) dz . For \int e^z \cos(z) dz, we use u = e^z and dv = \cos(z) dz. So du = e^z dz and v = \sin(z), and \int e^z \sin(z) dz \amp = -e^z \cos(z) + e^z \sin(z) dz - \int e^z \sin(z) dz2 \int e^z \sin(z) dz \amp = -e^z \cos(z) + e^z \sin(z) + c'\int e^z \sin(z) dz \amp = -\frac{1}{2}e^z \cos(z) + \frac{1}{2}e^z \sin(z) + c'

We use u = s^2, dv = e^{3s} ds, du = 2s ds, and v = \frac{1}{3} e^{3s}. This gives
\int s^2 e^{3s} ds = \frac{1}{3}s^2 e^{3s} - \frac{2}{3} \int s e^{3s} ds . We now use u = s, dv = e^{3s} ds, du = ds, and v = \dfrac{1}{3} e^{3s} for \int s e^{3s} ds. \int s^2 e^{3s} ds \amp = \frac{1}{3}s^2 e^{3s} - \frac{2}{3} \left( \frac{1}{3}s e^{3s} - \frac{1}{3}\int e^{3s} ds \right)\amp = \frac{1}{3}s^2 e^{3s} - \frac{2}{3} \left( \frac{1}{3}s e^{3s} - \frac{1}{9} e^{3s} \right) + c\amp = \frac{1}{3}s^2 e^{3s} - \frac{2}{9}s e^{3s} + \frac{2}{27} e^{3s} + c

statement.p: \int t \arctan(t) \,dt (Hint: At a certain point in this problem, it is very helpful to note that \frac{t^2}{1+t^2} = 1 - \frac{1}{1+t^2}.)

solution.p: Using u = \arctan(t), dv = t dt, du = \dfrac{1}{1+t^2} dt, and v = \dfrac{1}{2} t^2, we get \int t \arctan(t) dt \amp = \frac{1}{2}t^2 \arctan(t) - \frac{1}{2} \int \frac{t^2}{1 + t^2} dt\amp = \frac{1}{2}t^2 \arctan(t) - \frac{1}{2} \int \left( 1 - \frac{1}{1 + t^2} \right) dt\amp = \frac{1}{2}t^2 \arctan(t) - \frac{1}{2}t - \frac{1}{2} \arctan(t) + c
